In addition to advising graduate students, Professor Rodriguez often collaborates with external labs and industry partners to deploy research ideas in realistic settings, while maintaining a strong emphasis on conceptual clarity and reproducible results.

Their current research interests revolve around large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. Most recently, they have worked on projects related to agentic workflows and evaluation of language models, and they are beginning to investigate code generation. They have experience with reading and implementing recent research papers, setting up controlled experiments, and communicating results through written reports and presentations.

Professor background (field: LLM):
At Stanford University, Professor Rodriguez directs the Intelligent Systems Lab, a group that studies large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems from both methodological and applied perspectives. Their current research interests revolve around large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Rodriguez, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Rodriguez,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a research assistant in Computer Science with a strong interest in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on instruction tuning and preference optimization. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from retrieval-augmented generation and preference optimization, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on evaluation of language models, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Best regards,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Singh,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science with a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on preference optimization and multi-step reasoning. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies multimodal vision-language models and robustness and fairness in vision systems. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore 3D reconstruction and rendering, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on code generation and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Warm regards,
[Student Name]

Dear Professor Anderson,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science with a strong interest in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. In a separate course project, I began to explore reinforcement learning from human feedback, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on online algorithms, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

Yours sincerely,

Their research lies in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems, with a particular focus on multi-step reasoning, tool-augmented reasoning, and agentic workflows. In recent years, their group has published at top conferences and journals, developing both theoretical insights and large-scale systems. More recently, the group has been exploring safety alignment and robustness and related problems, aiming to connect rigorous foundations with practical impact in real-world applications. Professor Chen leads the Machine Learning and Reasoning Group, supervising graduate students and collaborating with international partners on ambitious, long-term research programs that span multiple subfields of LLM.

Student background (field: LLM):
The student is a master's student in Computer Science from a university in Latin America. Their current research interests revolve around large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. Most recently, they have worked on projects related to evaluation of language models and instruction tuning, and they are beginning to investigate multi-step reasoning. They have experience with reading and implementing recent research papers, setting up controlled experiments, and communicating results through written reports and presentations.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Chen, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Chen,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a master's student in Computer Science with a strong interest in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on tool-augmented reasoning and instruction tuning. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies retrieval-augmented generation and evaluation of language models. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore code generation, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on evaluation of language models and my interests in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a LLM-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Warm regards,
[Student Name]
rejected:

chosen:
Dear Professor Zhang,

My name is [Student Name], currently a first-year PhD student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on code generation and evaluation of language models, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies autonomous driving perception and 3D reconstruction and rendering. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore video understanding, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on agentic workflows, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

Dear Professor Wang,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a master's student in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. In a separate course project, I began to explore distributed computing, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. In your work on video understanding, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in theoretical computer science and algorithms. Best regards,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Chen,

My name is [Student Name], currently a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on code generation and evaluation of language models, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies medical image analysis and multimodal vision-language models. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore diffusion-based image generation, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on reinforcement learning from human feedback and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Martin,

My name is [Student Name], currently a master's student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on multi-step reasoning and tool-augmented reasoning, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. In a separate course project, I began to explore multimodal vision-language models, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on retrieval-augmented generation and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Best regards,
[Student Name]

Professor Patel is a faculty member in the Department of Computer Science at ETH Zürich. Their research lies in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems, with a particular focus on multi-step reasoning, agentic workflows, and code generation. In recent years, their group has published at top conferences and journals, developing both theoretical insights and large-scale systems. More recently, the group has been exploring evaluation of language models and related problems, aiming to connect rigorous foundations with practical impact in real-world applications. Professor Patel leads the Intelligent Systems Lab, supervising graduate students and collaborating with international partners on ambitious, long-term research programs that span multiple subfields of LLM.

Student background (field: CV):
The student is a first-year PhD student in Computer Science from a university in Europe. Their current research interests revolve around computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. Most recently, they have worked on projects related to 3D reconstruction and rendering and medical image analysis, and they are beginning to investigate video understanding. They have experience with reading and implementing recent research papers, setting up controlled experiments, and communicating results through written reports and presentations.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Patel, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Patel,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science with a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on reinforcement learning from human feedback and retrieval-augmented generation. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from self-supervised visual representation learning and robustness and fairness in vision systems, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on safety alignment and robustness, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Warm regards,
[Student Name]
rejected:
Dear Professor Patel,

I am reaching out to ask if you have any fully funded positions available in your lab. I am mainly looking for opportunities that can provide a strong stipend and possibly help with future immigration or work visas. From what I understand, professors in your department often have good funding, so I thought it would be a good idea to contact you.

I have studied computer science and done some small projects in different areas, but I am not yet sure what I want to specialize in. I am open to working on anything that is currently funded and that could lead to good job prospects later on. I hope that once I join your lab, you can assign me to a suitable topic and provide detailed guidance.

If possible, I would appreciate information about the exact amount of financial support, potential scholarships, and any guarantees regarding future PhD admission. These factors are very important to me in deciding which professor to work with. Please let me know as soon as you can.

Best,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Kim,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in TCS with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on probabilistic method and random graphs and distributed computing, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore instruction tuning, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on computational complexity theory, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. Dear Professor Davis,

My name is [Student Name], and I am a first-year PhD student in Computer Science with a strong interest in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I see a natural connection between your work on online algorithms and my interests in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Yours sincerely,

My name is [Student Name], currently a master's student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on agentic workflows and multi-step reasoning, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies autonomous driving perception and vision transformers. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore video understanding, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on preference optimization and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Best regards,
[Student Name]
rejected:
Dear Professor Chen,

I am writing this email because I am looking for a strong supervisor who can help me advance my career. I have consistently been among the top students in my program, and my friends often come to me for help with homework. I am sure that with the right advisor I can become a leading researcher in the field.

In the past, I have worked on many different projects, including web applications, mobile apps, and some basic data analysis. People often tell me that I am very talented and that I should aim high. I am especially interested in positions that will look good on my CV and help me get into a top PhD program in the future. I am confident that if I join your group, my profile will become much more competitive.

I have not yet looked closely at your specific research topics, but given your reputation I am sure that whatever you are doing is important. I hope you can suggest a project for me and maybe also introduce me to your collaborators when the time is right. Please let me know if you can offer me a position.

Best,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Johnson,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a research assistant in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on retrieval-augmented generation and safety alignment and robustness. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from sublinear-time algorithms and learning theory and generalization bounds, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in theoretical computer science and algorithms and develop a more critical reading habit.

I see a natural connection between your work on evaluation of language models and my interests in theoretical computer science and algorithms. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a TCS-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Rodriguez,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in TCS, I came across your work on sublinear-time algorithms and cryptography and secure computation. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies learning theory and generalization bounds and computational complexity theory. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore approximation algorithms, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on computational complexity theory, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in theoretical computer science and algorithms. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a TCS-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in TCS. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

Dear Professor Garcia,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. chosen:
Dear Professor Brown,

My name is [Student Name], currently a master's student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on agentic workflows and retrieval-augmented generation, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. In a separate course project, I began to explore probabilistic method and random graphs, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

In your work on preference optimization, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in theoretical computer science and algorithms. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. Dear Professor Nguyen,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a first-year PhD student in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on preference optimization and safety alignment and robustness. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from cryptography and secure computation and probabilistic method and random graphs, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in theoretical computer science and algorithms and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on reinforcement learning from human feedback, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in theoretical computer science and algorithms. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a TCS-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Kim,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in TCS with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on learning theory and generalization bounds and property testing, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies 3D reconstruction and rendering and robustness and fairness in vision systems. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore diffusion-based image generation, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on sublinear-time algorithms and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in TCS. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

Their research lies in theoretical computer science and algorithms, with a particular focus on probabilistic method and random graphs, sublinear-time algorithms, and approximation algorithms. In recent years, their group has published at top conferences and journals, developing both theoretical insights and large-scale systems. More recently, the group has been exploring property testing and related problems, aiming to connect rigorous foundations with practical impact in real-world applications. Professor Johnson leads the Machine Learning and Reasoning Group, supervising graduate students and collaborating with international partners on ambitious, long-term research programs that span multiple subfields of TCS.

Student background (field: CV):
As a master's student studying Computer Science in Latin America, the student has gradually developed a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. They have joined small research initiatives and course projects that exposed them to robustness and fairness in vision systems, medical image analysis, and object detection and segmentation, learning how to reproduce baselines, run ablations, and interpret noisy experimental results. These experiences have motivated them to search for more structured, long-term research mentorship.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Johnson, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Johnson,

My name is [Student Name], currently a first-year PhD student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in TCS with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on online algorithms and distributed computing, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from multimodal vision-language models and video understanding, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning and develop a more critical reading habit.

I see a natural connection between your work on cryptography and secure computation and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Best regards,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Liu,

My name is [Student Name], currently a master's student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in CV with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on diffusion-based image generation and self-supervised visual representation learning, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from retrieval-augmented generation and preference optimization, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on multimodal vision-language models, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

Dear Professor Davis,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in CV with practical impact. In a separate course project, I began to explore self-supervised visual representation learning, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on robustness and fairness in vision systems and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

Best regards,

In addition to advising graduate students, Professor Anderson often collaborates with external labs and industry partners to deploy research ideas in realistic settings, while maintaining a strong emphasis on conceptual clarity and reproducible results.
student_background: The student is a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science from a university in the United States. Their current research interests revolve around large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. Most recently, they have worked on projects related to tool-augmented reasoning and reinforcement learning from human feedback, and they are beginning to investigate retrieval-augmented generation. They have experience with reading and implementing recent research papers, setting up controlled experiments, and communicating results through written reports and presentations.

Professor background (field: CV):
At University of California, Berkeley, Professor Anderson directs the Data, Learning, and Decisions Group, a group that studies computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning from both methodological and applied perspectives. The group has an established track record in areas such as diffusion-based image generation, self-supervised visual representation learning, and 3D reconstruction and rendering, and is currently pushing into newer directions like autonomous driving perception. In addition to advising graduate students, Professor Anderson often collaborates with external labs and industry partners to deploy research ideas in realistic settings, while maintaining a strong emphasis on conceptual clarity and reproducible results.

The student is a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science from a university in the United States. Their current research interests revolve around large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. Most recently, they have worked on projects related to tool-augmented reasoning and reinforcement learning from human feedback, and they are beginning to investigate retrieval-augmented generation. They have experience with reading and implementing recent research papers, setting up controlled experiments, and communicating results through written reports and presentations.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Anderson, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Anderson,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in CV with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on diffusion-based image generation and autonomous driving perception, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from reinforcement learning from human feedback and multi-step reasoning, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on video understanding, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]
rejected:

I am reaching out to ask if you have any fully funded positions available in your lab. I am mainly looking for opportunities that can provide a strong stipend and possibly help with future immigration or work visas. From what I understand, professors in your department often have good funding, so I thought it would be a good idea to contact you.

I have studied computer science and done some small projects in different areas, but I am not yet sure what I want to specialize in. I am open to working on anything that is currently funded and that could lead to good job prospects later on. I hope that once I join your lab, you can assign me to a suitable topic and provide detailed guidance.

Dear Professor Kumar,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a master's student in Computer Science with a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore diffusion-based image generation, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on robustness and fairness in vision systems and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

My name is [Student Name], and I am a research assistant in Computer Science with a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In a separate course project, I began to explore multimodal vision-language models, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

chosen:
Dear Professor Liu,

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on learning theory and generalization bounds, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in theoretical computer science and algorithms. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Rodriguez, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. chosen:
Dear Professor Rodriguez,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a research assistant in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in TCS, I came across your work on online algorithms and distributed computing. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from online algorithms and distributed computing, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in theoretical computer science and algorithms and develop a more critical reading habit.

I see a natural connection between your work on computational complexity theory and my interests in theoretical computer science and algorithms. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a TCS-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in TCS. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Warm regards,
[Student Name]

My name is [Student Name], currently a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. Yours sincerely,

In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. chosen:
Dear Professor Liu,

My name is [Student Name], currently a research assistant in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in CV with practical impact. In a separate course project, I began to explore robustness and fairness in vision systems, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

Their research lies in theoretical computer science and algorithms, with a particular focus on cryptography and secure computation, approximation algorithms, and learning theory and generalization bounds. In recent years, their group has published at top conferences and journals, developing both theoretical insights and large-scale systems. More recently, the group has been exploring probabilistic method and random graphs and related problems, aiming to connect rigorous foundations with practical impact in real-world applications. Professor Lopez leads the Machine Learning and Reasoning Group, supervising graduate students and collaborating with international partners on ambitious, long-term research programs that span multiple subfields of TCS.

Student background (field: TCS):
As a master's student studying Computer Science in India, the student has gradually developed a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. They have joined small research initiatives and course projects that exposed them to cryptography and secure computation, probabilistic method and random graphs, and computational complexity theory, learning how to reproduce baselines, run ablations, and interpret noisy experimental results. These experiences have motivated them to search for more structured, long-term research mentorship.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Lopez, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Lopez,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in TCS, I came across your work on learning theory and generalization bounds and online algorithms. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from probabilistic method and random graphs and online algorithms, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in theoretical computer science and algorithms and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on sublinear-time algorithms, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in theoretical computer science and algorithms. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a TCS-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in TCS. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Martin,

My name is [Student Name], currently a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in CV with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on 3D reconstruction and rendering and vision transformers, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies vision transformers and object detection and segmentation. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore autonomous driving perception, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on diffusion-based image generation and my interests in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in CV. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Garcia,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a first-year PhD student in Computer Science with a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in CV, I came across your work on 3D reconstruction and rendering and video understanding. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies vision transformers and object detection and segmentation. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore autonomous driving perception, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on diffusion-based image generation, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in CV. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Zhang,

My name is [Student Name], currently a first-year PhD student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in CV with practical impact. Dear Professor Garcia,

chosen:
Dear Professor Davis,

My name is [Student Name], currently a master's student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on reinforcement learning from human feedback and code generation, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from agentic workflows and reinforcement learning from human feedback, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems and develop a more critical reading habit.

I see a natural connection between your work on instruction tuning and my interests in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]
