chosen:
Dear Professor Taylor,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a master's student in Computer Science with a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on preference optimization and reinforcement learning from human feedback. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from 3D reconstruction and rendering and diffusion-based image generation, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on instruction tuning, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

My name is [Student Name], currently a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

Yours sincerely,

prompt:
You are asked to write a cold email from a student to a professor about potential research opportunities.

Professor background (field: CV):
At Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Professor Garcia directs the Algorithms and Foundations Group, a group that studies computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning from both methodological and applied perspectives. The group has an established track record in areas such as vision transformers, self-supervised visual representation learning, and medical image analysis, and is currently pushing into newer directions like diffusion-based image generation. In addition to advising graduate students, Professor Garcia often collaborates with external labs and industry partners to deploy research ideas in realistic settings, while maintaining a strong emphasis on conceptual clarity and reproducible results.

Student background (field: CV):
The student is currently a first-year PhD student in Computer Science based in India, with an emerging focus on computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. Over the past year, they have taken advanced courses and completed independent projects on topics such as video understanding and robustness and fairness in vision systems, gaining familiarity with standard toolchains, evaluation protocols, and research practices. They are now especially interested in exploring 3D reconstruction and rendering more deeply under the guidance of an experienced advisor.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Garcia, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Garcia,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a master's student in Computer Science with a strong interest in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in CV, I came across your work on autonomous driving perception and robustness and fairness in vision systems. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from 3D reconstruction and rendering and medical image analysis, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning and develop a more critical reading habit.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on video understanding, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a CV-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in CV. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

Dear Professor Kumar,

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Warm regards,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Nguyen,

My name is [Student Name], currently a research assistant in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on safety alignment and robustness and instruction tuning, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies multi-step reasoning and reinforcement learning from human feedback. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore preference optimization, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on tool-augmented reasoning, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a LLM-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

Dear Professor Zhang,

Dear Professor Kim,

Dear Professor Kim,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

Sincerely,

chosen:
Dear Professor Wang,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a master's student in Computer Science with a strong interest in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on safety alignment and robustness and agentic workflows. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies tool-augmented reasoning and safety alignment and robustness. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore multi-step reasoning, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on evaluation of language models and my interests in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Nguyen,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science with a strong interest in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on preference optimization and multi-step reasoning. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies safety alignment and robustness and preference optimization. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore reinforcement learning from human feedback, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on agentic workflows and my interests in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read this email. I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Warm regards,
[Student Name]

Dear Professor Smith,

chosen:
Dear Professor Johnson,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in CV, I came across your work on object detection and segmentation and multimodal vision-language models. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

The group has an established track record in areas such as instruction tuning, evaluation of language models, and reinforcement learning from human feedback, and is currently pushing into newer directions like multi-step reasoning. In addition to advising graduate students, Professor Chen often collaborates with external labs and industry partners to deploy research ideas in realistic settings, while maintaining a strong emphasis on conceptual clarity and reproducible results.

Student background (field: LLM):
As a junior undergraduate student studying Computer Science in China, the student has gradually developed a strong interest in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. They have joined small research initiatives and course projects that exposed them to multi-step reasoning, safety alignment and robustness, and agentic workflows, learning how to reproduce baselines, run ablations, and interpret noisy experimental results. These experiences have motivated them to search for more structured, long-term research mentorship.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Chen, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Chen,

My name is [Student Name], currently a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on retrieval-augmented generation and code generation, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies reinforcement learning from human feedback and safety alignment and robustness. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore tool-augmented reasoning, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on multi-step reasoning, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a LLM-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Best regards,
[Student Name]

The student is currently a first-year PhD student in Computer Science based in China, with an emerging focus on theoretical computer science and algorithms. Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Kim, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Kim,

My name is [Student Name], currently a first-year PhD student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in CV with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on self-supervised visual representation learning and robustness and fairness in vision systems, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

My prior work has focused on relatively small-scale projects, but they have given me a useful foundation. For instance, I worked on a project combining ideas from cryptography and secure computation and probabilistic method and random graphs, where I was responsible for setting up the training pipeline, running controlled experiments, and documenting the findings. I also spent time replicating results from recent papers, which helped me build intuition for common failure modes in theoretical computer science and algorithms and develop a more critical reading habit.

I see a natural connection between your work on video understanding and my interests in theoretical computer science and algorithms. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Best regards,
[Student Name]

Sincerely,

chosen:
Dear Professor Davis,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a master's student in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in CV, I came across your work on medical image analysis and object detection and segmentation. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies distributed computing and learning theory and generalization bounds. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore probabilistic method and random graphs, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on diffusion-based image generation and my interests in theoretical computer science and algorithms. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I understand that you receive many similar messages and that your schedule is very busy, so I would be grateful for even a brief reply or any pointers you might be willing to share. Regardless of your current availability, I have learned a great deal from reading your papers and will continue to follow your work with interest.

Yours sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Smith,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. Professor background (field: LLM):
At Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Professor Anderson directs the Algorithms and Foundations Group, a group that studies large language models, natural language processing, and AI systems from both methodological and applied perspectives. The group has an established track record in areas such as preference optimization, multi-step reasoning, and evaluation of language models, and is currently pushing into newer directions like agentic workflows. In addition to advising graduate students, Professor Anderson often collaborates with external labs and industry partners to deploy research ideas in realistic settings, while maintaining a strong emphasis on conceptual clarity and reproducible results.

The student is a junior undergraduate student in Computer Science from a university in India. Their current research interests revolve around computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. They have experience with reading and implementing recent research papers, setting up controlled experiments, and communicating results through written reports and presentations.

Task: Write a polite, detailed, and well-structured cold email from the student to Professor Anderson, asking about the possibility of joining the professor's group for research. The email should accurately reflect the professor's research directions, clearly explain how the student's background connects to these directions, ask one or two concrete questions about potential projects or preparation, and be appropriate for an initial contact.
chosen:
Dear Professor Anderson,

My name is [Student Name], currently a final-year undergraduate student in Computer Science, and I have been looking for research groups whose work bridges foundational ideas in LLM with practical impact. In that search, I have repeatedly encountered your papers on tool-augmented reasoning and safety alignment and robustness, which stood out for their clear problem statements and careful empirical methodology. Reading these papers convinced me that your group would be an ideal environment to grow as a researcher.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies autonomous driving perception and vision transformers. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore robustness and fairness in vision systems, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

What especially resonates with me is your emphasis on connecting conceptual clarity with careful experimentation. In your work on multi-step reasoning, I see opportunities to apply and extend the skills I have been developing in computer vision, visual recognition, and multimodal learning. I am particularly curious about how these ideas might scale to more complex tasks or more realistic data regimes, and I would be eager to help explore such directions.

If you are currently considering new students or remote collaborators, I would be honored if you could keep me in mind. Even if that is not possible at the moment, I would greatly appreciate any suggestions you might have regarding papers to study, skills to strengthen, or small self-contained problems that would prepare me to work in your area. If you see a potential fit, I would be happy to share a CV, transcripts, or a short summary of my current projects.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Sincerely,
[Student Name]

chosen:
Dear Professor Davis,

I hope this message finds you well. My name is [Student Name], and I am a first-year PhD student in Computer Science with a strong interest in theoretical computer science and algorithms. While exploring research at the intersection of theory and practice in LLM, I came across your work on instruction tuning and multi-step reasoning. I was impressed by how your papers connect careful problem formulations with both rigorous analysis and thoughtful empirical validation. The broader agenda of your group, as described on your website, aligns closely with the kind of long-term research direction I hope to pursue in graduate school.

Over the past year, I have been involved in a project that studies learning theory and generalization bounds and computational complexity theory. In this project, I implemented several baselines, designed ablation studies, and helped maintain a reproducible experimental pipeline under limited compute. This taught me how to read and critique recent papers, formulate clear hypotheses, and debug both code and ideas. In a separate course project, I began to explore cryptography and secure computation, which made me appreciate the challenges of balancing theoretical elegance with practical constraints. Although my current results are still modest, these experiences have convinced me that I enjoy sustained, open-ended research.

I see a natural connection between your work on reinforcement learning from human feedback and my interests in theoretical computer science and algorithms. In particular, I am interested in how the techniques you develop could be extended to settings where models must operate under resource constraints or interact with noisy, real-world data. I would be very excited to contribute to projects that aim to push the boundary of what is possible in this direction, whether by helping with implementation and experimental design, or by working on smaller theoretical questions that fit into a larger agenda.

I am writing to ask whether you might be open to supervising a student with my background in the coming year. If possible, I would be grateful for any advice on how someone with primarily a TCS-oriented background could best prepare to contribute to your research program in LLM. For example, I would be very interested to know whether there are specific readings, tools, or prerequisite concepts you would recommend that I focus on over the next several months. I would also be curious to hear whether there are ongoing projects in your group where a motivated junior researcher could start by assisting with experiments, code refactoring, or preliminary analyses.

I truly appreciate your time and consideration. Even if you are not currently able to take on additional students, any brief feedback or guidance you could offer would mean a lot to me. Thank you again for your contributions to the field and for inspiring students like me.

Best regards,
[Student Name]
